intro: Teramnus hookerianus, commonly known as the Hooker's teramnus, is a flowering plant species native to the Andes mountains of South America. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its woody stems and large, palmate leaves that can reach up to 30 centimeters in diameter. It produces showy, yellow flowers with five petals, which bloom in the spring. Due to its unique morphology and limited distribution, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species in its native habitat.
